questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because she has had dyspnea and palpitations with mild exertion for the past 8 days. Initially, the symptoms subsided immediately after cessation of activity, but they have worsened and now last up to 45 minutes. The patient returned from a summer camping trip in Vermont 6 weeks ago. She says she had “an episode of flu” with fever and chills 1 month ago. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 56 years. She drinks two to four beers on social occasions and occasionally smokes marijuana. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 47/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 150/70 mm Hg. A resting ECG is shown. Two-step serological testing confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In a young patient with cardiac symptoms (e.g., palpitations, dyspnea), AV block, or other cardiac arrhythmias a few weeks to months after a possible infection with Borrelia burgdorferi, there should be a high level of suspicion for Lyme carditis. Cardiac manifestations are a feature of early disseminated Lyme disease, which typically occurs 3–10 weeks after a tick bite. Intravenous ceftriaxone is the first-line treatment for adults and children with severe Lyme carditis (i.e., symptomatic patients, first-degree AV block with PR interval ≥ 300 ms, second- or third-degree AV block). Other severe manifestations of Lyme disease that warrant hospitalization and intravenous antibiotic therapy include encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, and persistent arthritis.

Less severe manifestations of Lyme disease (e.g., mild carditis, isolated cranial nerve palsy, migratory arthralgias) should be treated with oral doxycycline or amoxicillin (in patients who are pregnant or lactating).

B) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin is the first-line treatment for pregnant or lactating patients with Lyme disease who do not require hospitalization, such as those with mild carditis (i.e., first-degree AV block with PR interval < 300 ms). In patients with more severe manifestations of Lyme disease, another form of therapy is indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

As beta blockers have negative inotropic, dromotropic, and chronotropic effects, which typically lead to decreased blood pressure and decreased oxygen consumption by the heart, they can be used to treat hypertension and heart failure. Beta-blocker therapy would likely worsen this patient's bradycardia and is contraindicated in patients with AV block.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline is the first-line treatment for most patients with Lyme disease who do not require hospitalization, such as those with mild carditis (i.e., first-degree AV block with PR interval < 300 ms). In patients with more severe manifestations of Lyme disease, another form of therapy is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Atropine, a muscarinic antagonist, may be indicated in cases of bradycardia. However, the patient is young, hemodynamically stable, and her symptoms are not severe. Furthermore, she has an AV block associated with early disseminated Lyme disease, so it is important to first treat the underlying cause. Additionally, atropine affects the sinus node as opposed to the AV node.

F) INCORRECT:

Permanent pacemaker implantation is not usually necessary to treat an AV block caused by Lyme carditis. Temporary pacemaker implantation may be required, however, in severe cases (e.g., second-degree AV block, Mobitz II or third-degree AV block) or in patients who are hemodynamically unstable.
questions.hint: Although no tick bite or rash (erythema migrans) have been reported, an episode of flu-like symptoms shortly after a camping trip to an endemic area (Northeast and Upper Midwest of the US) should raise concern for Lyme disease, which is diagnosed with two-step serological testing (ELISA followed by Western blot). The ECG strip shows progressively longer PR intervals before a QRS is dropped and resets the cycle, indicating second-degree AV block, Mobitz I.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of confusion and rapidly progressive dyspnea. He has had a fever and chills for the past five days. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with hepatitis C. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 15 years and drinks one to two beers daily. He has a history of past intravenous heroin use. He appears pale, anxious, and in severe distress. His temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), respirations are 30/min, pulse is 59/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 75%. Examination shows multiple linear hemorrhages underneath the nails. There are nontender maculae on both palms and soles. Fine rales are heard bilaterally on auscultation of the chest. Cardiac examination shows an S3; a grade 3/6 high-pitched decrescendo early diastolic murmur is heard along the left sternal border and right second intercostal space. An x-ray of the chest shows a normal-sized heart and pulmonary edema. An ECG shows P waves and QRS complexes that occur at regular intervals, but independently of each other. Transesophageal echocardiography of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: A highly echogenic, thin, linear structure in the right atrium
Heterogeneous mass attached to the interatrial septum
Anechoic space between pericardium and epicardium
Perivalvular thickening with an echolucent cavity
Oscillating mobile mass on the tricuspid valve
Eccentric hypertrophy of the left ventricle

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A highly echogenic, thin, linear structure in the right atrium indicates a pacemaker or implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). This patient neither has a history of cardiac disease (e.g., arrhythmias) nor a history of ICD placement.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac myxoma is the most common primary tumor of the heart in adults and usually presents with an early diastolic sound. Patients may also have constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss, night sweats) and repeated syncopal episodes. Although this patient has an early diastolic murmur and fever, he has not had syncope, weight loss, or night sweats. Additionally, he has specific findings (splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions) indicating IE rather than cardiac myxoma.

C) INCORRECT:

An anechoic space between the pericardium and epicardium is seen in patients with cardiac tamponade. Patients with cardiac tamponade typically present with hypotension, muffled heart sounds, distended neck veins, tachycardia, pulsus paradoxus, and electrical alternans on the ECG.

D) CORRECT:

Perivalvular thickening with an echolucent cavity indicates perivalvular abscess formation, a severe complication of IE that develops when infection spreads to the valve annulus and/or cardiac septum. Conduction abnormalities on ECG (e.g., AV block) occur when the abscess extends to cardiac conduction tissues, and they are most commonly seen in patients with aortic valve involvement. Perivalvular abscess is associated with high mortality if left untreated, as well as additional complications such as systemic embolization and acute coronary syndrome (due to coronary compression).

Always suspect a perivalvular abscess in patients with IE who develop a new conduction abnormality.
Image Description:

Echocardiography (transesophageal; biplane mid-esophageal) of patient with aortic valve bioprosthesis, fever, chest discomfort, and increasing shortness of breath

A mobile hyperechoic mass on the aortic valve (arrow) is suspicious for infectious endocarditis. Additional hyperechoic perivalvular thickening (arrowhead) suggests the presence of a valve ring abscess.

Ao: aorta; IAS: interatrial septum; LA: left atrium; LV: left ventricle; MV: mitral valve; RA: right atrium; RV: right ventricle; TV: tricuspid valve

E) INCORRECT:

An oscillating mobile mass on the tricuspid valve would be seen in patients with IE that affects the tricuspid valve. Right-sided IE usually occurs in individuals who inject drugs. However, right-sided valvular lesions rarely lead to conduction abnormalities. Instead, conduction abnormalities are usually associated with IE of the aortic valve, which is consistent with this patient's auscultatory findings.

F) INCORRECT:

Eccentric hypertrophy of the left ventricle (LV) is typically seen in chronic aortic regurgitation. Although this patient presents with acute aortic regurgitation, he is unlikely to have eccentric hypertrophy since the aortic regurgitation is new-onset. ECG findings in patients with LV hypertrophy include left axis deviation and a positive Sokolow-Lyon index, but this patient's ECG shows a third-degree atrioventricular block. Although this patient may develop eccentric hypertrophy as a complication if he is not properly treated, it is unlikely at this time.
questions.hint: The combination of fever, splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions, and a heart murmur characteristic of aortic regurgitation suggests infective endocarditis (IE). Rapidly progressive dyspnea, bilateral rales on auscultation, pulmonary edema, hypotension, and hypoxia are consistent with acute heart failure. ECG findings show a third-degree atrioventricular (AV) block.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of two episodes of bright red blood per rectum within the past day. She has a history of migraine, which is treated prophylactically with verapamil. She appears well. Her pulse is 81/min and blood pressure is 124/80 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Her abdomen is mildly tender without rebound or guarding. Digital rectal examination shows fresh blood on the glove. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.4 g/dL


Leukocyte count
5000/mm3



Platelet count
175,000/mm3



Partial thromboplastin time
35 seconds


Serum



 Na+

140 mEq/L


 K+

3.7 mEq/L


 Cl-

101 mEq/L


 HCO3-

25 mEq/L


 Mg2+

1.8 mg/dL


An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management with respect to this patient's cardiovascular workup?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atropine temporarily inhibits vagal activity and can improve conduction through the AV node, which shortens the PR interval. It would be indicated if this patient were hemodynamically unstable due to bradycardia from her first-degree AV block. However, this patient is asymptomatic.

B) INCORRECT:

Adenosine slows conduction through the AV node and would likely further prolong this patient's PR interval and worsen her first-degree AV block. Therefore, adenosine would not be recommended here.

C) CORRECT:

Calcium-channels blockers such as verapamil can lead to PR interval prolongation and first-degree AV block, as seen here. Since this patient is asymptomatic and has no evidence of underlying structural heart disease or electrolyte disturbances, the prolonged PR interval is most likely a benign finding that only requires observation. A follow-up ECG should be done to monitor for any disease progression.

See “Overview of atrioventricular blocks” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Cardioversion is indicated in patients who are hemodynamically unstable due to SVT or monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. This patient's ECG is consistent with first-degree AV block, for which synchronized cardioversion is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers, such as metoprolol, slow conduction through the AV node and would likely further prolong this patient's PR interval and worsen her first-degree AV block. Therefore, metoprolol would not be recommended here.

F) INCORRECT:

Pacemaker placement is usually not indicated in first-degree AV block unless it manifests with wide QRS complexes on ECG. If her AV block became symptomatic (bradycardia, dizziness, syncope), verapamil would first be discontinued before pacemaker placement was considered.

G) INCORRECT:

An electrophysiological study should be considered in patients with a first-degree AV block and wide QRS complexes, the combination of which raises suspicion for an infranodal block. Since infranodal blocks can spontaneously progress to high-grade AV block and cause hemodynamic instability, further investigation to localize the site of the lesion and, potentially, pacemaker placement are needed in these patients. This patient's ECG, however, shows no signs of an infranodal block.
questions.hint: This patient's ECG shows a sinus rhythm with PR intervals > 0.2 s, which is consistent with a first-degree atrioventricular block (AV block).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He underwent appendectomy at the age of 25 years. He has a history of hypercholesterolemia that is well controlled with atorvastatin. He is an avid marathon runner and runs 8 miles per day four times a week. His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 42 years. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. His vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. His abdomen is soft and nontender with a surgical scar in the right lower quadrant. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A myocardial infarction (MI) most commonly occurs in individuals with coronary heart disease secondary to atherosclerosis. While this patient's risk for a MI is increased (positive family history, hypercholesterolemia) and an atypical presentation with few symptoms (e.g., no dyspnea, chest pain) is possible, his ECG findings indicate another condition rather than MI. Typical ECG findings in MI include ST elevations (STEMI), peaked T waves, absence of R waves, terminal T-wave inversions, or pathological Q-wave formations.
Image Description:

ECG schematic (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

–Left: normal ECG
–Top right: upwardly convex ST elevation from descending limb of the R wave
–Bottom right: slightly upwardly concave (borderline horizontal) ST elevation from ascending limb of the S wave

B) INCORRECT:

A third-degree AV block is characterized by a complete interruption of atrioventricular conduction, characterized by P waves and QRS complexes that occur at regular intervals but are dissociated from one another. The resulting bradycardia and possible brief episodes of asystole may lead to cerebral hypoperfusion (e.g., fatigue, dizziness), dyspnea, Stokes-Adams attacks, or cardiac arrest. This patient's ECG indicates impaired AV conduction, but not a complete block.
Image Description:

ECG schematic (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

P waves occur at a regular rate of ∼ 83/min in all tracings. However, in third-degree AV block, there is no conduction between atria and ventricles, resulting in an escape rhythm being generated by pacemaker cells in more distal sites. Ventricular rate and QRS morphology vary according to the site of origin of the escape rhythm: the more distal the site of impulse generation, the slower the rhythm and the wider the QRS complex.

Sinus rhythm (top): rate ∼ 83/min

Third-degree AV block with junctional escape rhythm (middle)
– AV dissociation (no relationship between P waves and QRS complexes)
– Ventricular rate of ∼ 45/min and narrow QRS complexes indicate that the escape rhythm is generated at the level of the AV node

Third-degree AV block with ventricular escape rhythm (bottom)
– AV dissociation
– Ventricular rate of ∼ 25/min and wide QRS complexes indicate that the escape rhythm is generated at the level of the bundle of His

C) INCORRECT:

An ECG of a Mobitz type II AV block typically shows single or intermittent nonconducted P waves that are not followed by QRS complexes. In contrast to the ECG seen in this patient, the PR interval remains constant. In addition, the resulting bradycardia leads to reduced cardiac output and causes symptoms of fatigue, dizziness, and dyspnea that are not seen in this patient.
Image Description:

15-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Irregularly irregular rhythm
– Atrial rate ~70/min, ventricular rate ~40/min
– Left axis deviation (LAD): R > S in lead I (+), R < S in II and aVF (-)
– Right bundle branch block (RBBB): QRS is widened (∼150 ms) with RBBB morphology (green overlay).
– Left anterior fascicular block (LAD and qR in aVL)
– Regular P waves throughout (red overlay), with intermittent nonconducted P waves (circled P)
– AV conduction ratio (P:QRS): initially 3:2, then 2:1
– PR interval: prolonged (∼240 ms) but constant in the conducted beats

The intermittent nonconducted P waves, with constant PR in the conducted beats, indicate Mobitz II second-degree atrioventricular block (which may have a regular conduction ratio or be completely irregular). The combination of RBBB and left anterior fascicular block represents a bifascicular block.

D) CORRECT:

This patient presents with typical features of Mobitz type I AV block on ECG. The condition is usually asymptomatic but may manifest with an irregular pulse, bradycardia, reduced cardiac output, and subsequent symptoms of hypoperfusion (e.g., dizziness, syncope). Treatment is recommended for symptomatic and/or hemodynamically unstable patients (e.g., pacemaker, atropine). Although no immediate treatment is necessary, the patient should be clinically assessed for underlying diseases (e.g., structural heart diseases, electrolyte imbalances) and receive follow-ups with cardiac monitoring to evaluate the progression of the disease. See “Overview of atrioventricular blocks” table.
Image Description:

ECG schematic of types of second-degree atrioventricular block (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– P waves occur at a regular rate of ∼78/min in all tracings.
– Mobitz I/Wenckebach (top): There is progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a P wave is not conducted (in this example, the fourth, which is not followed by a QRS complex) and the progression restarts.
– 2:1 block (middle): The PR interval is constant but only every second P wave is conducted to the ventricles to trigger a QRS complex.
– High-grade block (bottom): The PR interval is constant but ≥2 consecutive P waves are not conducted to the ventricles. In this example, only every third P wave triggers a QRS complex (a 3:1 block).

E) INCORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation (Afib) is a sustained cardiac arrhythmia characterized by an altered heart rate (most commonly tachycardia), indiscernible P waves, and narrow QRS complexes on ECG. While individuals with Afib are often asymptomatic, the absence of typical findings on ECG rules out this diagnosis.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25mm/s)

- Irregularly irregular rhythm
- Rate ∼ 90/min
- Normal axis
- No discernable P waves
- Coarse fibrillatory waves (f waves) are visible, particularly in II, aVF and V1

F) INCORRECT:

Atrial flutter (Aflut) is a supraventricular tachyarrhythmia that shows a characteristic sawtooth appearance of the P waves with a rate of approx. 300 bpm, and regular, but narrow QRS complexes. While Aflut is more common in men and tends to be asymptomatic, the absence of typical features on ECG rules out this diagnosis.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Atrial rate ∼ 240/min, ventricular rate ∼ 60/min (4:1 AV conduction ratio)
– Left axis deviation: R > S in I (green complex); S > R in aVF (red complex)
– P waves with a “sawtooth” appearance (flutter waves)
– Regular, narrow QRS complexes
– Prolonged PR interval (∼ 280 ms)
– Horizontal ST depression (0.1–0.2 mV) with T-wave inversion in leads I and V2–V6, suggestive of myocardial ischemia

These findings indicate atrial flutter with 4:1 conduction, probably secondary to the observed myocardial ischemia.

G) INCORRECT:

First-degree AV blocks are often an incidental finding on ECG in otherwise healthy individuals (e.g., athletes). While the condition is usually asymptomatic, a characteristic feature is a PR interval > 200 ms with a normal atrial to ventricular conduction, which rules out the diagnosis in this patient.
Image Description:

ECG schematic (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Top: normal PR interval
– Bottom (first-degree atrioventricular block): PR interval ≥0.2 s

H) INCORRECT:

Ventricular fibrillation (VF) is a life-threatening cardiac arrhythmia most commonly associated with coronary heart disease (CHD). While this patient is at increased risk for CHD (positive family history, hypercholesterolemia), he shows no symptoms of VF (e.g., chest pain, palpitations, dyspnea). The absence of typical features on ECG, including absent atrial P waves, indiscernible QRS complexes, and tachycardia > 300 bpm rule out this diagnosis.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– No discernible P waves, QRS complexes, or T waves
– Absence of the normal isoelectric baseline
– Chaotic irregular deflections representing disorganized electrical activity in the ventricles with a rate of ∼ 375/min

Diagnosis: ventricular fibrillation. Note that this rhythm results in loss of cardiac output and is fatal unless resuscitation is rapidly commenced.
questions.hint: The ECG of this patient shows a steady increase of the PR intervals until a QRS complex is dropped completely. These features are associated with a specific cardiac condition that is usually asymptomatic.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of fatigue and lightheadedness. He does not have chest pain, palpitations, or difficulty breathing. He has a history of hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. Seven months ago, he had a myocardial infarction. His medications are simvastatin, lisinopril, metoprolol, and ibuprofen. His pulse is 48/min and blood pressure is 89/50 mm Hg. He responds slowly to questions but is oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. His lungs are clear to auscultation and bowel sounds are positive, with no pulsatile masses or bruits. Pedal pulses are nonpalpable, distal extremities are cold, and capillary refill time is 4 seconds. An ECG shows left axis deviation, a pathologic Q wave in lead III, a wide QRS complex, and a constant PR interval of 0.15 seconds; every third P wave is nonconducted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amiodarone is typically indicated for the management of refractory ventricular and supraventricular tachyarrhythmias. This drug is associated with an increased risk of sinus bradycardia and AV nodal block and is therefore contraindicated in this patient who is already bradycardic and has a second-degree AV block.

B) INCORRECT:

Glucagon is used in the treatment of patients with beta-blocker poisoning, which can manifest with bradycardia and signs of cardiogenic shock. However, ECG in patients with beta-blocker poisoning typically shows sinus bradycardia and a prolonged PR interval, consistent with first-degree AV block. This patient presents with a Mobitz type II AV block, for which glucagon is not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Digoxin decreases AV node conduction and is used to treat atrial fibrillation and heart failure in treatment-resistant cases. This drug is contraindicated in patients with second-degree AV block because it can worsen AV conduction delay and thereby increase the risk of complete AV block.

D) INCORRECT:

Adenosine decreases AV node conduction and is typically indicated for the acute management of persistent paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia. This drug is contraindicated in patients with second-degree AV block because it can worsen AV conduction delay and thereby increase the risk of complete AV block.

E) CORRECT:

Mobitz type II AV block is an unstable bradyarrhythmia that requires immediate treatment because it can progress to third-degree heart block and death. The first step in management is to determine hemodynamic status. Unstable patients require immediate treatment with transcutaneous (or transvenous) cardiac pacing. Placing a transcutaneous pacemaker is only a temporary measure until the patient is hemodynamically stable and can be further evaluated and treated for reversible causes of AV block. In patients with no reversible causes, definitive treatment includes placement of a permanent pacemaker to bypass the AV nodal block.

In addition to temporary cardiac pacing, prompt treatment with atropine and beta-adrenergic agents (e.g., dopamine, dobutamine, epinephrine) may be indicated. Administration of IV atropine is the first-line treatment for most cases of symptomatic bradycardia. However, in patients with an infranodal block, such as Mobitz type II AV block, atropine is often ineffective and may in rare cases worsen the symptoms.
Image Description:

15-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Irregularly irregular rhythm
– Atrial rate ~70/min, ventricular rate ~40/min
– Left axis deviation (LAD): R > S in lead I (+), R < S in II and aVF (-)
– Right bundle branch block (RBBB): QRS is widened (∼150 ms) with RBBB morphology (green overlay).
– Left anterior fascicular block (LAD and qR in aVL)
– Regular P waves throughout (red overlay), with intermittent nonconducted P waves (circled P)
– AV conduction ratio (P:QRS): initially 3:2, then 2:1
– PR interval: prolonged (∼240 ms) but constant in the conducted beats

The intermittent nonconducted P waves, with constant PR in the conducted beats, indicate Mobitz II second-degree atrioventricular block (which may have a regular conduction ratio or be completely irregular). The combination of RBBB and left anterior fascicular block represents a bifascicular block.
questions.hint: This patient is hemodynamically unstable (lightheadedness, hypotension, cool extremities, delayed capillary refill) with ECG evidence of a Mobitz type II AV block (bradycardia with a constant PR interval and regular nonconducted P waves in a 3:2 ratio), which is typically due to an infranodal block.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after a syncopal episode 2 hours ago while grocery shopping. She has been feeling fatigued and lightheaded for the past couple of days. She has hypertension. Current medications include carvedilol. She appears diaphoretic. She is oriented to person but not to place or time. Her blood pressure is 95/62 mm Hg. An ECG is shown. A bolus of intravenous atropine is administered, after which vital signs remain unchanged. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation with continuous telemetry may be an appropriate option for patients with asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable bradycardia. Hemodynamically unstable patients with third-degree AV block, however, require intervention, as they are at high risk of asystole and sudden cardiac death.

B) INCORRECT:

Adenosine causes a short-term heart block by slowing down conduction in the atrioventricular node. It is used for the diagnosis and termination of certain forms of paroxysmal tachyarrhythmias (e.g., AVNRT and orthodromic AVRT) but would worsen this patient's heart block.

C) CORRECT:

Transcutaneous (or transvenous) cardiac pacing is indicated in patients with symptomatic high-risk AV blocks (e.g., Mobitz type II block or third-degree block). Transcutaneous pacing is only a temporary measure. Once the patient is stabilized, the cause of the third-degree AV block should be investigated, followed by a long-term solution (e.g., permanent cardiac pacing) if no reversible cause is found. This patient's third-degree AV block is likely an adverse effect of her medication (a beta blocker) and may be reversed with drug discontinuation.
Image Description:

ACS: acute coronary syndrome
CCBs: calcium channel blockers
ECG: electrocardiogram
IV: intravenous
PPM: permanent pacemaker
TTE: transthoracic echocardiography

D) INCORRECT:

The implantation of a cardiac defibrillator is indicated in patients at high risk for ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation to prevent sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia. However, there is no evidence of ventricular arrhythmia in this patient and a permanent defibrillator would not address her third-degree AV block.

E) INCORRECT:

Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic medication that can be used in patients with ventricular arrhythmia, supraventricular arrhythmia, and cardiac arrest. Since amiodarone decreases AV node conduction and would thus exacerbate this patient's third-degree AV block, it is contraindicated here.
questions.hint: This patient's ECG shows a slow ventricular rhythm (∼ 27/min) with complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes. These findings are consistent with a third-degree atrioventricular block (complete AV block). Her hypotension and confusion should raise concern for inadequate perfusion and impending shock.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department for chest pain that started 1 hour ago. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He appears diaphoretic and distressed. An ECG shows P waves independent of QRS complexes. The QRS interval is 0.11 seconds with normal morphology. Which of the following is the most likely trigger of this patient's ventricular contractions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An electrical rhythm generated from the SA node (the natural pacemaker of the heart) results in normal narrow QRS complexes, as seen in this ECG. However, the P waves will always precede the QRS complex at regular, fixed intervals, which is not seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

The Bachmann bundle conducts electrical impulses from the SA node to the left atrium; it is not part of the ventricular portion of the cardiac conduction pathway. The Bachmann bundle is not known to serve as an ectopic pacemaker; however, electric activity originating there would theoretically pass through the SA node to the AV node and result in P waves that precede the QRS complex at regular, fixed intervals, which is not seen here.

C) CORRECT:

In complete heart block, electrical impulses from the SA node are not conducted to the ventricles. Myocytes of the cardiac conduction pathway have the potential to spontaneously depolarize and behave as pacemakers when they do not receive signals from the SA node, which results in escape rhythms. Depending on the shape of the QRS complexes of the escape rhythms, the site of these ectopic pacemakers can be determined. Normal, narrow QRS complexes as seen on this ECG are triggered by impulses anywhere from the SA node up to the bundle of His (i.e., the block is at or proximal to the bundle of His).
Image Description:

The subepicardial sinus node generates electrical impulses, which then travel through the walls of the atria to the subendocardial atrioventricular node. After a short delay in the atrioventricular node, the impulses pass through the bundle of His (situated in the membranous part of interventricular septum) to the Tawara branches. These then terminate in numerous small fibers (Purkinje fibers), which activate the heart muscle cells of the chambers and thus initiate cardiac contraction.

D) INCORRECT:

An ectopic pacemaker located in the Purkinje fibers results in wide QRS complexes because the rate of conduction of the electrical impulse to the ventricles is much slower than when it originates from the SA node.

E) INCORRECT:

An ectopic pacemaker located in either the left or the right bundle branch of the cardiac conduction pathway results in wide QRS complexes because the rate of conduction of the electrical impulse to the ventricles is much slower than when it originates from the SA node.

F) INCORRECT:

An atrial ectopic pacemaker generates an escape rhythm characterized by an abnormal P wave that precedes every QRS complex. The QRS complexes would be normal because the atrioventricular conduction is normal (i.e., via the His-Purkinje pathway). This patient's ECG shows normal P waves independent of the QRS complexes.
questions.hint: An ECG that shows P waves independent of QRS complexes indicates complete heart block; the atria and ventricles are contracting independently of each other. The normally-shaped QRS complexes indicate that there is an ectopic pacemaker elsewhere along the conduction pathway.

questions.text: Twelve hours after being admitted to the hospital for an inferior wall myocardial infarction, a 65-year-old woman begins to present with dyspnea, dizziness, and syncopal episodes that last a few seconds. Her pulse is 40/min. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

First-degree atrioventricular blocks (AV blocks) can develop after an acute inferior myocardial infarction (the right coronary artery also supplies the atrioventricular node, which is where this block occurs). However, patients with first-degree AV block are typically asymptomatic. Moreover, the condition is characterized by a prolonged PR interval (> 200 ms) with a QRS complex following every P wave (i.e., all P waves are conducted through to the ventricles), which is not the case here.
Image Description:

ECG schematic (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Top: normal PR interval
– Bottom (first-degree atrioventricular block): PR interval ≥0.2 s

B) INCORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation (Afib) is a common complication of acute myocardial infarction that can cause dyspnea, dizziness, and syncope, as seen here. However, Afib is characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm with varying RR intervals and absent P waves. Moreover, Afib is commonly associated with a rapid ventricular response (ventricular rate > 100 bpm), which is not consistent with this patient's bradycardia.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Irregularly irregular rhythm (examples of the irregular R-R intervals are indicated by red arrows)

– Average ventricular rate ∼ 84/min (14 QRS complexes can be seen on the 10-second rhythm strip)

– No discernable P waves

– Narrow QRS complexes (examples indicated by green lines)

– Normal cardiac axis

These findings are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

C) INCORRECT:

Dyspnea, dizziness, syncopal episodes, and bradycardia may rarely be seen in Mobitz type I block, a potential complication of an inferior myocardial infarction (the right coronary artery also supplies the atrioventricular node, which is where this block occurs). However, Mobitz type I blocks are characterized by progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a beat is dropped (i.e., a nonconducted P wave that is not followed by a QRS complex), which is not the case here.
Image Description:

ECG strip (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular P waves at a rate of ∼80/min (green overlay)
– There is progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a P wave is not conducted (in this example, the fourth, which is not followed by a QRS complex) and the progression restarts.

D) INCORRECT:

Dyspnea, dizziness, and syncope may rarely be seen in sinus bradycardia, a potential complication of an inferior myocardial infarction (because the right coronary artery also supplies the sinoatrial node). However, the ECG in patients with sinus bradycardia shows P waves of normal morphology that are always followed by QRS complexes, which is not the case here.

E) INCORRECT:

Atrial flutter (Aflut) can complicate an acute myocardial infarction and cause dyspnea, dizziness, and syncope (even though most patients with Aflut are asymptomatic). However, Aflut is a type of supraventricular tachycardia that is typically associated with a fast heart rate, which is not consistent with this patient's bradycardia. Moreover, flutter waves (i.e., sawtooth appearance of P waves that occur in sequence at a rate of ∼ 300 bpm), which are the characteristic ECG finding in Aflut, are not seen here.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Atrial rate ∼ 240/min, ventricular rate ∼ 60/min (4:1 AV conduction ratio)
– Left axis deviation: R > S in I (green complex); S > R in aVF (red complex)
– P waves with a “sawtooth” appearance (flutter waves)
– Regular, narrow QRS complexes
– Prolonged PR interval (∼ 280 ms)
– Horizontal ST depression (0.1–0.2 mV) with T-wave inversion in leads I and V2–V6, suggestive of myocardial ischemia

These findings indicate atrial flutter with 4:1 conduction, probably secondary to the observed myocardial ischemia.

F) INCORRECT:

Dyspnea, dizziness, syncopal episodes, bradycardia, and ECG showing atrioventricular dissociation after a recent myocardial infarction may raise suspicion for a Mobitz type II block (due to damage to the His-Purkinje system, which is where this block most commonly occurs). However, Mobitz type II blocks are characterized by intermittent dropped beats (i.e., nonconducted P waves that are not followed by QRS complexes) and a constant PR interval, which is not the case here.
Image Description:

15-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Irregularly irregular rhythm
– Atrial rate ~70/min, ventricular rate ~40/min
– Left axis deviation (LAD): R > S in lead I (+), R < S in II and aVF (-)
– Right bundle branch block (RBBB): QRS is widened (∼150 ms) with RBBB morphology (green overlay).
– Left anterior fascicular block (LAD and qR in aVL)
– Regular P waves throughout (red overlay), with intermittent nonconducted P waves (circled P)
– AV conduction ratio (P:QRS): initially 3:2, then 2:1
– PR interval: prolonged (∼240 ms) but constant in the conducted beats

The intermittent nonconducted P waves, with constant PR in the conducted beats, indicate Mobitz II second-degree atrioventricular block (which may have a regular conduction ratio or be completely irregular). The combination of RBBB and left anterior fascicular block represents a bifascicular block.

G) CORRECT:

This patient's dyspnea, dizziness, syncopal episodes (Stokes-Adams attacks), bradycardia, recent inferior myocardial infarction (MI), and ECG findings are consistent with a third-degree atrioventricular block (i.e., complete AV block). This condition is characterized by AV dissociation, in which the atria (P waves) and the ventricles (QRS complexes) beat independently of one another. Third-degree AV blocks occur due to impaired conduction at the level of the AV node (∼ 20%), bundle of His, or below the His bundle (most common; ∼ 60%). A block above the His bundle is associated with narrow QRS complexes (< 120 ms), while a block below the His bundle is characterized by wide QRS complexes. Additionally, the atrial rate is greater than the ventricular rate (i.e., more P waves than QRS complexes) and both atrial and ventricular rates are constant.

Third-degree AV block may complicate an inferior MI (because the AV node and His bundle are primarily supplied by the right coronary artery) or an anterior MI (because the His bundle may receive blood from the septal branches of the left coronary artery). Other causes of third-degree AV block include infections (e.g., Lyme disease, bacterial endocarditis), cardiomyopathy, hyperkalemia, and iatrogenic effects (e.g., cardiac interventions, drugs such as beta-blockers).
questions.hint: This patient's ECG shows a ventricular rate of 40/min and an atrial rate of 100/min. The placement of a temporary transcutaneous or transvenous pacemaker is indicated.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man reports intermittent dizziness and two episodes of syncope. The first episode occurred while he was watching television at home 2 weeks ago; the second episode occurred this morning after he stood up from the breakfast table.
The patient’s medical history includes hypertension and mild nonobstructive coronary artery disease. He currently takes aspirin 81 mg daily, lisinopril 5 mg daily, and simvastatin 20 mg daily. A previous electrocardiogram (figure 1) documents trifascicular block (concomitant first-degree heart block, left anterior fascicular block, and right bundle-branch block).
Neurologic and cardiac examinations are within normal limits.
Orthostatic vital signs show normal blood pressure and heart rate response to a change in position. A new electrocardiogram is obtained (figure 2).
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate in this patient?

choices.text: Discontinue lisinopril and refer for tilt-table testing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although Holter monitoring is useful in delineating the presence of transient heart block or other arrhythmias, the ECG finding of complete heart block is an adequate indication for pacemaker implantation.

B) INCORRECT:

Tilt-table testing is not indicated, as the patient has no signs of orthostasis or positional syncope.

C) INCORRECT:

Cerebral imaging is not indicated, as the patient has no residual deficits to suggest a stroke.

D) INCORRECT:

Stress testing would be indicated if chronotropic incompetence/bradycardia were postulated as a cause of functional impairment and syncope.

E) CORRECT:

Features on the patient’s baseline electrocardiogram (ECG) include sinus rhythm with a right bundle-branch block and left anterior fascicular block (so-called bifascicular block) and a concomitant first-degree atrioventricular block; thus, he is said to have incomplete trifascicular block. The repeat ECG reveals complete heart block, a serious condition that requires intervention. Permanent pacemaker implantation in patients with bifascicular block is often guided by symptoms (e.g., syncope, dizziness, and exertional intolerance) after other causes of syncope have been reasonably excluded. However, once the condition has progressed to complete heart block, a permanent pacemaker is indicated.

Key learning point: The development of complete heart block in a patient with a chronic bifascicular conduction abnormality is a class I indication for permanent pacemaker implantation.

questions.text:
An 84-year-old man presents to the emergency department after an episode of sudden loss of consciousness when walking from a chair to the bathroom. During the fall, he sustained a superficial laceration to the head. According to his wife, he regained consciousness 1 to 2 minutes after falling. He did not have chest pain, palpitations, or other prodromal symptoms.
He is currently being treated for hypertension and type 2 diabetes with hydrochlorothiazide, amlodipine, and metformin. Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography less than one year ago showed no evidence of obstructive coronary artery disease.
His initial electrocardiogram showed normal sinus rhythm at a heart rate of 80 beats per minute. His blood pressure is within the normal range without orthostatic changes. Laboratory evaluation at his current visit reveals normal kidney function and electrolyte levels, as well as a normal concentration of thyroid-stimulating hormone.
A follow-up electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Refer for placement of a permanent pacemaker

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s electrocardiogram demonstrates 2:1 second-degree heart block (i.e., presence of two P waves for every QRS, with a fixed PR interval). The tracing also reveals features of an incomplete right bundle-branch block, which provides further evidence of conduction-system disease. In the presence of symptoms and in the absence of a reversible cause, patients with 2:1 heart block should receive a permanent pacemaker.

Patients with Mobitz type II second-degree heart block (i.e., presence of blocked P waves with at least two consecutively conducted P waves with a fixed PR interval) are usually symptomatic; progression to third-degree heart block is common and sudden. A permanent pacemaker is indicated for patients with Mobitz type II second-degree heart block, even in the absence of symptoms.

Key learning point: Intermittent 2:1 second-degree heart block in a patient with a recent episode of syncope is an indication for placement of a permanent pacemaker.

B) INCORRECT:

Myocardial ischemia may cause intermittent heart block, usually on exertion. If the patient’s presentation suggests the presence of ischemia, further workup should precede placement of a permanent device. In this older patient with recent coronary angiography showing no obstructive coronary artery disease, conduction-system disease is the more likely cause of symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Amlodipine is a dihydropyridine calcium-channel blocker with minimal effect on atrioventricular conduction.

D) INCORRECT:

An invasive electrophysiology study is indicated if the site of the heart block is unclear. This patient already has a strong indication for pacing, and an additional invasive procedure is unnecessary.

E) INCORRECT:

Metformin use is not associated with the development of heart block.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old girl is brought in by her parents, who report that she has complained of feeling dizzy several times during the past month while playing with friends on the playground. During these episodes, she has looked pale and needed to stop and rest for a few minutes. Her teachers also note that she has seemed more tired than usual during the past 4 to 6 weeks. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications.
On physical examination, she appears well and is alert and interactive. She has a heart rate of 54 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 104/40 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air. She has a normal S1 and a split S2 . She has a 2/6 short systolic ejection murmur best heard at the left midsternal border. She has normal peripheral pulses, has no cyanosis, and is warm and well perfused. She has no hepatomegaly.
An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following cardiac conduction abnormalities is the cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

First-degree AV block is characterized by a prolonged PR interval. A PR interval is consistent with first-degree AV block if it is ≥120 msec for an infant, ≥150 msec for a toddler, ≥170 msec for school-age children (ages 3–8), ≥180 msec in pubescent children (ages 9–12), and ≥190 msec in teens (ages 13–18). There are some variations in these numbers based on the patient’s heart rate. In this patient’s ECG, one can see variable PR intervals, some short and some very prolonged. Most children with first-degree AV heart block are asymptomatic and do not progress to more-severe types of heart block.

B) INCORRECT:

At first glance, the ECG findings could appear to be consistent with sinus bradycardia. The QRS complexes do occur at a slowed regular interval. However, when one begins to examine their occurrence in relation to the P waves, it becomes clear that not every P wave is associated with a corresponding QRS complex. In sinus bradycardia, a QRS complex follows every P wave.

C) INCORRECT:

Second-degree AV block, Mobitz type 2, is characterized by occasional all-or-none conduction through the ventricle — some P waves are followed by a QRS complex; others are not. Mobitz type 2 is a very concerning rhythm and, because of the risk for sudden death, is a class I indication for pacemaker placement. This patient’s ECG is consistent with third-degree AV block, not second-degree block.

D) INCORRECT:

Second-degree AV block, Mobitz type 1, is characterized by a gradual lengthening of the PR interval until the QRS complex is dropped because the sinus impulse is blocked from conduction through the ventricle. In this patient’s ECG, there is no pattern to the length of the PR interval relative to the QRS complex. Most children with Mobitz type 1 are not symptomatic, and this type of heart block does not progress to more-severe forms of heart block.

E) CORRECT:

Syncope that occurs with physical activity, particularly vigorous activity, is very concerning for underlying cardiac pathology. This patient’s heart rate of 54 beats per minute is concerning for a bradyarrhythmia, necessitating an electrocardiogram (ECG) for further investigation. A normal heart rate for a 9-year-old child that is awake is 70 to 110 beats per minute.

This patient’s ECG shows the characteristic findings of third-degree atrioventricular (AV) block, whereby conduction is blocked at the AV node or the His-Purkinje system. The atrial activity (P waves) occurs independently of ventricular activity (QRS complexes). In this patient, the atrial rate is 78 beats per minute, and there is a narrow QRS junctional escape rhythm at 44 beats per minute. The presence of symptoms depends on the rate and reliability of the ventricular rate. When the rate is faster than 40 beats per minute at rest, the patient may have few complaints. However, when the patient is active, symptoms may become evident, as in this case. Third-degree AV block is associated with fatigue, dyspnea, exercise intolerance, and presyncope. Other symptoms can include chest pain, syncope, and sudden cardiac arrest.

Key learning point: Electrocardiographic evidence of atrial activity (P waves) that occurs independent of ventricular activity (QRS complexes) characterizes the type of heart block known as third-degree atrioventricular block.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He has a history of hypercholesterolemia that is well controlled with atorvastatin. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vital signs are normal. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. Electrocardiography is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Second-degree AV block Mobitz type II
Second-degree AV block Mobitz type I

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A third-degree AV block is characterized by a complete interruption of atrioventricular conduction, characterized by P waves and QRS complexes that occur at regular intervals but are dissociated from one another. The resulting bradycardia and possible brief episodes of asystole may lead to cerebral hypoperfusion (e.g., fatigue, dizziness), dyspnea, Stokes-Adams attacks, or cardiac arrest. This patient's ECG indicates impaired AV conduction, but not a complete block.
Image Description:

ECG schematic (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

P waves occur at a regular rate of ∼ 83/min in all tracings. However, in third-degree AV block, there is no conduction between atria and ventricles, resulting in an escape rhythm being generated by pacemaker cells in more distal sites. Ventricular rate and QRS morphology vary according to the site of origin of the escape rhythm: the more distal the site of impulse generation, the slower the rhythm and the wider the QRS complex.

Sinus rhythm (top): rate ∼ 83/min

Third-degree AV block with junctional escape rhythm (middle)
– AV dissociation (no relationship between P waves and QRS complexes)
– Ventricular rate of ∼ 45/min and narrow QRS complexes indicate that the escape rhythm is generated at the level of the AV node

Third-degree AV block with ventricular escape rhythm (bottom)
– AV dissociation
– Ventricular rate of ∼ 25/min and wide QRS complexes indicate that the escape rhythm is generated at the level of the bundle of His

B) INCORRECT:

An ECG of a Mobitz type II AV block typically shows single or intermittent nonconducted P waves that are not followed by QRS complexes. In contrast to the ECG seen in this patient, the PR interval remains constant. In addition, the resulting bradycardia leads to reduced cardiac output and causes symptoms of fatigue, dizziness, and dyspnea that are not seen in this patient.
Image Description:

15-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Irregularly irregular rhythm
– Atrial rate ~70/min, ventricular rate ~40/min
– Left axis deviation (LAD): R > S in lead I (+), R < S in II and aVF (-)
– Right bundle branch block (RBBB): QRS is widened (∼150 ms) with RBBB morphology (green overlay).
– Left anterior fascicular block (LAD and qR in aVL)
– Regular P waves throughout (red overlay), with intermittent nonconducted P waves (circled P)
– AV conduction ratio (P:QRS): initially 3:2, then 2:1
– PR interval: prolonged (∼240 ms) but constant in the conducted beats

The intermittent nonconducted P waves, with constant PR in the conducted beats, indicate Mobitz II second-degree atrioventricular block (which may have a regular conduction ratio or be completely irregular). The combination of RBBB and left anterior fascicular block represents a bifascicular block.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with typical features of Mobitz type I AV block on ECG. The condition is usually asymptomatic but may manifest with an irregular pulse, bradycardia, reduced cardiac output, and subsequent symptoms of hypoperfusion (e.g., dizziness, syncope). Treatment is recommended for symptomatic and/or hemodynamically unstable patients (e.g., pacemaker, atropine). Although no immediate treatment is necessary, the patient should be clinically assessed for underlying diseases (e.g., structural heart diseases, electrolyte imbalances) and receive follow-ups with cardiac monitoring to evaluate the progression of the disease. See “Overview of atrioventricular blocks” table.

Key learning point: Mobitz type I (Wenckebach) AV block is characterized by progressively lengthening PR intervals followed by a dropped QRS complex and is usually asymptomatic.
Image Description:

ECG schematic of types of second-degree atrioventricular block (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– P waves occur at a regular rate of ∼78/min in all tracings.
– Mobitz I/Wenckebach (top): There is progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a P wave is not conducted (in this example, the fourth, which is not followed by a QRS complex) and the progression restarts.
– 2:1 block (middle): The PR interval is constant but only every second P wave is conducted to the ventricles to trigger a QRS complex.
– High-grade block (bottom): The PR interval is constant but ≥2 consecutive P waves are not conducted to the ventricles. In this example, only every third P wave triggers a QRS complex (a 3:1 block).

D) INCORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation (Afib) is a sustained cardiac arrhythmia characterized by an altered heart rate (most commonly tachycardia), indiscernible P waves, and narrow QRS complexes on ECG. While individuals with Afib are often asymptomatic, the absence of typical findings on ECG rules out this diagnosis.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25mm/s)

- Irregularly irregular rhythm
- Rate ∼ 90/min
- Normal axis
- No discernable P waves
- Coarse fibrillatory waves (f waves) are visible, particularly in II, aVF and V1

E) INCORRECT:

First-degree AV blocks are often an incidental finding on ECG in otherwise healthy individuals. While the condition is usually asymptomatic, a characteristic feature is a PR interval > 200 ms with a normal atrial to ventricular conduction, which rules out the diagnosis in this patient.
Image Description:

ECG schematic (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Top: normal PR interval
– Bottom (first-degree atrioventricular block): PR interval ≥0.2 s
questions.hint: The ECG of this patient shows a steady increase of the PR intervals until a QRS complex is dropped completely. These features are associated with a specific cardiac condition that is usually asymptomatic.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after a syncopal episode 2 hours ago. She has been feeling fatigued and lightheaded for the past couple of days. She has hypertension. Current medications include carvedilol. She appears diaphoretic. She is oriented to person but not to place or time. Her blood pressure is 88/62 mm Hg. Electrocardiography is shown. A bolus of intravenous atropine is administered, after which vital signs remain unchanged. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation with continuous telemetry may be an appropriate option for patients with asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable bradycardia. Hemodynamically unstable patients with third-degree AV block, however, require intervention, as they are at high risk of asystole and sudden cardiac death.

B) INCORRECT:

Adenosine causes a short-term heart block by slowing down conduction in the atrioventricular node. It is used for the diagnosis and termination of certain forms of paroxysmal tachyarrhythmias (e.g., AVNRT and orthodromic AVRT) but would worsen this patient's heart block.

C) CORRECT:

Transcutaneous (or transvenous) cardiac pacing is indicated in patients with symptomatic high-risk AV blocks (e.g., Mobitz type II block or third-degree block). Transcutaneous pacing is only a temporary measure. Once the patient is stabilized, the cause of the third-degree AV block should be investigated, followed by a long-term solution (e.g., permanent cardiac pacing) if no reversible cause is found. This patient's third-degree AV block is likely an adverse effect of her medication (a beta blocker) and may be reversed with drug discontinuation.
Image Description:

ACS: acute coronary syndrome
CCBs: calcium channel blockers
ECG: electrocardiogram
IV: intravenous
PPM: permanent pacemaker
TTE: transthoracic echocardiography

D) INCORRECT:

The implantation of a cardiac defibrillator is indicated in patients at high risk for ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation to prevent sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia. However, there is no evidence of ventricular arrhythmia in this patient and a permanent defibrillator would not address her third-degree AV block.

E) INCORRECT:

Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic medication that can be used in patients with ventricular arrhythmia, supraventricular arrhythmia, and cardiac arrest. Since amiodarone decreases AV node conduction and would thus exacerbate this patient's third-degree AV block, it is contraindicated here.
questions.hint: This patient's ECG shows a slow ventricular rhythm (∼ 27/min) with complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes. These findings are consistent with a third-degree atrioventricular block (complete AV block). Her hypotension and confusion should raise concern for inadequate perfusion and impending shock.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the office for a health maintenance examination. She has a history of migraine, which is treated prophylactically with verapamil. The patient feels well. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Electrocardiography is shown. Results of serum studies are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management with respect to this patient's cardiovascular workup?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atropine temporarily inhibits vagal activity and can improve conduction through the AV node, which shortens the PR interval. It would be indicated if this patient were hemodynamically unstable due to bradycardia from her first-degree AV block. However, this patient is asymptomatic.

B) INCORRECT:

Adenosine slows conduction through the AV node and would likely further prolong this patient's PR interval and worsen her first-degree AV block. Therefore, adenosine would not be recommended here.

C) CORRECT:

Calcium-channels blockers such as verapamil can lead to PR interval prolongation and first-degree AV block, as seen here. Since this patient is asymptomatic and has no evidence of underlying structural heart disease or electrolyte disturbances, the prolonged PR interval is most likely a benign finding that only requires observation. A follow-up ECG should be done to monitor for any disease progression.

See “Overview of atrioventricular blocks” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Cardioversion is indicated in patients who are hemodynamically unstable due to SVT or monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. This patient's ECG is consistent with first-degree AV block, for which synchronized cardioversion is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers, such as metoprolol, slow conduction through the AV node and would likely further prolong this patient's PR interval and worsen her first-degree AV block. Therefore, metoprolol would not be recommended here.
questions.hint: This patient's ECG shows a sinus rhythm with PR intervals > 0.2 s, which is consistent with a first-degree atrioventricular block (AV block).

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of dyspnea and palpitations with mild exertion. The patient returned from a summer camping trip in Vermont 6 weeks ago. She had fever, chills, and a circular rash on her arm shortly after the camping trip, which have since resolved. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Electrocardiography shows a second-degree AV block Mobitz type I. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In a young patient with cardiac symptoms (e.g., palpitations, dyspnea), AV block, or other cardiac arrhythmias a few weeks to months after a possible infection with Borrelia burgdorferi, there should be a high level of suspicion for Lyme carditis. Cardiac manifestations are a feature of early disseminated Lyme disease, which typically occurs 3–10 weeks after a tick bite. Intravenous ceftriaxone is the first-line treatment for adults and children with severe Lyme carditis (i.e., symptomatic patients, first-degree AV block with PR interval ≥ 300 ms, second- or third-degree AV block). Other severe manifestations of Lyme disease that warrant hospitalization and intravenous antibiotic therapy include encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, and persistent arthritis. Less severe manifestations of Lyme disease (e.g., mild carditis, isolated cranial nerve palsy, migratory arthralgias) should be treated with oral doxycycline (or amoxicillin in patients who are pregnant or lactating).

Lyme disease is diagnosed with two-step serological testing (ELISA followed by Western blot).

B) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin is the first-line treatment for pregnant or lactating patients with Lyme disease who do not require hospitalization, such as those with mild carditis (i.e., first-degree AV block with PR interval < 300 ms). In patients with more severe manifestations of Lyme disease, another form of therapy is indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

As beta blockers have negative inotropic, dromotropic, and chronotropic effects, which typically lead to decreased blood pressure and decreased oxygen consumption by the heart, they can be used to treat hypertension and heart failure. Beta-blocker therapy is contraindicated in patients with AV block.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline is the first-line treatment for most patients with Lyme disease who do not require hospitalization, such as those with mild carditis (i.e., first-degree AV block with PR interval < 300 ms). In patients with more severe manifestations of Lyme disease, another form of therapy is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Permanent pacemaker implantation is not usually necessary to treat an AV block caused by Lyme carditis. Temporary pacemaker implantation may be required, however, in severe cases (e.g., second-degree AV block Mobitz type II or third-degree AV block) or in patients who are hemodynamically unstable.
questions.hint: Although no tick bite has been reported, an episode of flu-like symptoms and a circular rash (erythema migrans) shortly after a camping trip to an endemic area (Northeast and Upper Midwest of the US) should raise concern for Lyme disease.

questions.text: Twelve hours after being admitted to the hospital for an inferior wall myocardial infarction, a 65-year-old woman begins to present with dyspnea, dizziness, and syncopal episodes that last a few seconds. Her pulse is 40/min. Electrocardiography is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation (Afib) is a common complication of acute myocardial infarction that can cause dyspnea, dizziness, and syncope, as seen here. However, Afib is characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm with varying RR intervals and absent P waves. Moreover, Afib is commonly associated with a rapid ventricular response (ventricular rate > 100 bpm), which is not consistent with this patient's bradycardia.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Irregularly irregular rhythm (examples of the irregular R-R intervals are indicated by red arrows)

– Average ventricular rate ∼ 84/min (14 QRS complexes can be seen on the 10-second rhythm strip)

– No discernable P waves

– Narrow QRS complexes (examples indicated by green lines)

– Normal cardiac axis

These findings are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

B) INCORRECT:

Dyspnea, dizziness, syncopal episodes, and bradycardia may rarely be seen in Mobitz type I block, a potential complication of an inferior myocardial infarction (the right coronary artery also supplies the atrioventricular node, which is where this block occurs). However, Mobitz type I blocks are characterized by progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a beat is dropped (i.e., a nonconducted P wave that is not followed by a QRS complex), which is not the case here.
Image Description:

ECG strip (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular P waves at a rate of ∼80/min (green overlay)
– There is progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a P wave is not conducted (in this example, the fourth, which is not followed by a QRS complex) and the progression restarts.

C) INCORRECT:

Dyspnea, dizziness, and syncope may rarely be seen in sinus bradycardia, a potential complication of an inferior myocardial infarction (because the right coronary artery also supplies the sinoatrial node). However, the ECG in patients with sinus bradycardia shows P waves of normal morphology that are always followed by QRS complexes, which is not the case here.

D) INCORRECT:

Atrial flutter (Aflut) can complicate an acute myocardial infarction and cause dyspnea, dizziness, and syncope (even though most patients with Aflut are asymptomatic). However, Aflut is a type of supraventricular tachycardia that is typically associated with a fast heart rate, which is not consistent with this patient's bradycardia. Moreover, flutter waves (i.e., sawtooth appearance of P waves that occur in sequence at a rate of ∼ 300 bpm), which are the characteristic ECG finding in Aflut, are not seen here.
Image Description:

15-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Irregularly irregular rhythm
– Atrial rate ~70/min, ventricular rate ~40/min
– Left axis deviation (LAD): R > S in lead I (+), R < S in II and aVF (-)
– Right bundle branch block (RBBB): QRS is widened (∼150 ms) with RBBB morphology (green overlay).
– Left anterior fascicular block (LAD and qR in aVL)
– Regular P waves throughout (red overlay), with intermittent nonconducted P waves (circled P)
– AV conduction ratio (P:QRS): initially 3:2, then 2:1
– PR interval: prolonged (∼240 ms) but constant in the conducted beats

The intermittent nonconducted P waves, with constant PR in the conducted beats, indicate Mobitz II second-degree atrioventricular block (which may have a regular conduction ratio or be completely irregular). The combination of RBBB and left anterior fascicular block represents a bifascicular block.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's dyspnea, dizziness, syncopal episodes (Stokes-Adams attacks), bradycardia, recent inferior myocardial infarction (MI), and ECG findings are consistent with a third-degree atrioventricular block (i.e., complete AV block). This condition is characterized by AV dissociation, in which the atria (P waves) and the ventricles (QRS complexes) beat independently of one another. Third-degree AV blocks occur due to impaired conduction at the level of the AV node (∼ 20%), bundle of His, or below the His bundle (most common; ∼ 60%). A block above the His bundle is associated with narrow QRS complexes (< 120 ms), while a block below the His bundle is characterized by wide QRS complexes. Additionally, the atrial rate is greater than the ventricular rate (i.e., more P waves than QRS complexes) and both atrial and ventricular rates are constant.

Third-degree AV block may complicate an inferior MI (because the AV node and His bundle are primarily supplied by the right coronary artery) or an anterior MI (because the His bundle may receive blood from the septal branches of the left coronary artery). Other causes of third-degree AV block include infections (e.g., Lyme disease, bacterial endocarditis), cardiomyopathy, hyperkalemia, and iatrogenic effects (e.g., cardiac interventions, drugs such as beta-blockers).
questions.hint: This patient's ECG shows a ventricular rate of 40/min and an atrial rate of 100/min. The placement of a temporary transcutaneous or transvenous pacemaker is indicated.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with hypertension and coronary artery disease reports intermittent dizziness and two episodes of syncope. He currently takes aspirin, lisinopril, and simvastatin. A previous electrocardiography (ECG) shows trifascicular block (concomitant first-degree heart block, left anterior fascicular block, and right bundle-branch block). Neurologic and cardiac examinations are within normal limits. Orthostatic vital signs show normal blood pressure and heart rate response to a change in position. A new ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discontinue lisinopril and refer for tilt-table testing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tilt-table testing is not indicated, as the patient has no signs of orthostasis or positional syncope.

B) INCORRECT:

Stress testing would be indicated if chronotropic incompetence/bradycardia were postulated as a cause of functional impairment and syncope.

C) CORRECT:

A right bundle-branch block, left anterior fascicular block (so-called bifascicular block), and a concomitant first-degree atrioventricular block are consistent with incomplete trifascicular block. The repeat ECG reveals complete heart block, a serious condition that requires intervention. Permanent pacemaker implantation in patients with bifascicular block is often guided by symptoms (e.g., syncope, dizziness, and exertional intolerance) after other causes of syncope have been reasonably excluded. However, once the condition has progressed to complete heart block, a permanent pacemaker is indicated.

Key learning point: The development of complete heart block in a patient with a chronic bifascicular conduction abnormality is a class I indication for permanent pacemaker implantation.

D) INCORRECT:

Cerebral imaging is not indicated, as the patient has no residual deficits to suggest a stroke.

E) INCORRECT:

Although Holter monitoring is useful in delineating the presence of transient heart block or other arrhythmias, the ECG finding of complete heart block is an adequate indication for pacemaker implantation.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man presents with progressive episodes of lightheadedness and near-syncope over the past month. He has a history of coronary artery disease. He denies chest pain or palpitations but notes mild shortness of breath on exertion. Examination shows a regularly slow pulse (see image). Serum electrolytes are within normal limits.


Heart rate
36 beats/min


Blood pressure
110/70 mm Hg


What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous isoproterenol, a beta-adrenergic agonist, increases heart rate by enhancing nodal automaticity and conduction. However, in complete AV block, the block is often infranodal, and isoproterenol does not restore AV synchrony. Additionally, it increases myocardial oxygen consumption, potentially exacerbating ischemia in patients with coronary artery disease. Its efficacy is limited in structural conduction system disease.

B) CORRECT:

Complete heart block, or third-degree atrioventricular (AV) block, is characterized by complete dissociation between atrial and ventricular activity, as seen in this patient's electrocardiogram. The atrial rate is independent of the slower ventricular rate, leading to significant hemodynamic compromise due to reduced cardiac output. Symptoms such as lightheadedness and near-syncope indicate a clinically significant conduction defect. In patients with a history of coronary artery disease, ischemic damage to the conduction system may cause irreversible tissue damage. A permanent pacemaker restores adequate ventricular rate and synchrony between atrial and ventricular contractions, stabilizing hemodynamics and aligning with management guidelines for symptomatic third-degree AV block.

Key learning point: Complete heart block is characterized by AV dissociation and requires a permanent pacemaker for definitive treatment to restore synchronized atrioventricular conduction and alleviate symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous atropine is effective for bradycardia due to increased vagal tone or intrinsic AV nodal dysfunction, as it enhances AV node conduction. However, in complete heart block, the conduction interruption is often infranodal, within the His-Purkinje system, which is less responsive to atropine. The patient's age and coronary artery disease history suggest structural conduction system disease, making atropine unlikely to improve the ventricular rhythm.

D) INCORRECT:

Coronary angiography is indicated for suspected myocardial ischemia, typically presenting with chest pain, dynamic ECG changes, or hemodynamic instability. This patient has symptomatic bradycardia with complete AV block, stable blood pressure, and no chest pain, suggesting intrinsic conduction system pathology rather than acute coronary syndrome. Urgent angiography does not address the bradyarrhythmia's underlying mechanism.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to your clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. He reports feeling well. He has a history of hypercholesterolemia, which is well controlled with atorvastatin. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vital signs are normal. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. Electrocardiography is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Second-degree AV block Mobitz type I.
Second-degree AV block Mobitz type II.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

First-degree AV blocks are often an incidental finding on ECG in otherwise healthy individuals. While the condition is usually asymptomatic, a characteristic feature is a PR interval > 200 ms with a normal atrial to ventricular conduction, which rules out the diagnosis in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

This patient presents with typical features of Mobitz type I AV block on ECG. The condition is usually asymptomatic but may manifest with an irregular pulse, bradycardia, reduced cardiac output, and subsequent symptoms of hypoperfusion (e.g., dizziness, syncope). Treatment is recommended for symptomatic and/or hemodynamically unstable patients (e.g., pacemaker, atropine). Although no immediate treatment is necessary, the patient should be clinically assessed for underlying diseases (e.g., structural heart diseases, electrolyte imbalances) and receive follow-ups with cardiac monitoring to evaluate the progression of the disease. See “Overview of atrioventricular blocks” table.

Key learning point: Mobitz type I (Wenckebach) AV block is characterized by progressive PR interval prolongation followed by a dropped QRS complex and is usually asymptomatic, often requiring no treatment unless symptoms develop.
Image Description:

ECG schematic of types of second-degree atrioventricular block (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– P waves occur at a regular rate of ∼78/min in all tracings.
– Mobitz I/Wenckebach (top): There is progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a P wave is not conducted (in this example, the fourth, which is not followed by a QRS complex) and the progression restarts.
– 2:1 block (middle): The PR interval is constant but only every second P wave is conducted to the ventricles to trigger a QRS complex.
– High-grade block (bottom): The PR interval is constant but ≥2 consecutive P waves are not conducted to the ventricles. In this example, only every third P wave triggers a QRS complex (a 3:1 block).

C) INCORRECT:

Atrial fibrillation (Afib) is a sustained cardiac arrhythmia characterized by an altered heart rate (most commonly tachycardia), indiscernible P waves, and narrow QRS complexes on ECG. While individuals with Afib are often asymptomatic, the absence of typical findings on ECG rules out this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A third-degree AV block is characterized by a complete interruption of atrioventricular conduction, characterized by P waves and QRS complexes that occur at regular intervals but are dissociated from one another. The resulting bradycardia and possible brief episodes of asystole may lead to cerebral hypoperfusion (e.g., fatigue, dizziness), dyspnea, Stokes-Adams attacks, or cardiac arrest. This patient's ECG indicates impaired AV conduction, but not a complete block.

E) INCORRECT:

An ECG of a Mobitz type II AV block typically shows single or intermittent nonconducted P waves that are not followed by QRS complexes. In contrast to the ECG seen in this patient, the PR interval remains constant. In addition, the resulting bradycardia leads to reduced cardiac output and causes symptoms of fatigue, dizziness, and dyspnea that are not seen in this patient.
questions.hint: The ECG of this patient shows a steady increase of the PR intervals until a QRS complex is dropped completely. These features are associated with a specific cardiac condition that is usually asymptomatic.

questions.text: Twelve hours after being admitted to hospital for an inferior wall myocardial infarction, a 65-year-old woman develops dyspnea, dizziness, and brief syncopal episodes. Her pulse is 40/min. Electrocardiography is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atrial flutter (Aflut) can complicate an acute myocardial infarction and cause dyspnea, dizziness, and syncope (even though most patients with Aflut are asymptomatic). However, Aflut is a type of supraventricular tachycardia that is typically associated with a fast heart rate, which is not consistent with this patient's bradycardia. Moreover, flutter waves (i.e., sawtooth appearance of P waves that occur in sequence at a rate of ∼ 300 bpm), which are the characteristic ECG finding in Aflut, are not seen here.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's dyspnea, dizziness, syncopal episodes (Stokes-Adams attacks), bradycardia, recent inferior myocardial infarction (MI), and ECG findings are consistent with a third-degree atrioventricular block (i.e., complete AV block). This condition is characterized by AV dissociation, in which the atria (P waves) and the ventricles (QRS complexes) beat independently of one another. Third-degree AV blocks occur due to impaired conduction at the level of the AV node (∼ 20%), bundle of His, or below the His bundle (most common; ∼ 60%). A block above the His bundle is associated with narrow QRS complexes (< 120 ms), while a block below the His bundle is characterized by wide QRS complexes. Additionally, the atrial rate is greater than the ventricular rate (i.e., more P waves than QRS complexes) and both atrial and ventricular rates are constant.
